0.22.text:
Christina: Brad, I just want to tell you that
you caused me a lot of trouble. I was at Stanford.

6.25.text:
I was at a debate with two feminist professors
from the law school, and at one point, I brought

12.45.text:
up your research on the importance of stable
families, fathers, and its relation to the

20.78.text:
absence of fathers and the relation to poverty.
Soon as I mentioned that fatherlessness was...a

27.23.text:
culture of fatherlessness was dysfunctional,
there were gasps. The woman next to me I was

32.38.text:
debating is very reasonable, seemingly reasonable
professor of law. She was horrified and simply

41.55.text:
to mention your research, what seems quite
sound to me, I triggered the audience, the

45.87.text:
whole audience. Have you met that reaction
or did I put it the wrong way? Well, you have

52.72.text:
no idea what I said, but I thought it was
an accurate representation of your research.

56.73.text:
Brad: Well, I think in some precincts of the
academy and the public culture, talking of

61.43.text:
fatherhood as an important part of kids' lives
is triggering. But I think it's also important

67.58.text:
to understand and to acknowledge that for
more mainstream scholars in psychology, and

72.18.text:
sociology, and economics, people like Bill Saw,
Hewlett Brookings, people like Sara McLanahan

77.18.text:
at Princeton, people like in Bertrand at the
University of Chicago, there is, I think,

81.19.text:
a recognition that fathers on average matter
for their kids and that communities that don't

88.28.text:
have lots of fathers are more likely to be
struggling in important ways. So, I think

93.19.text:
part of it is how close you are to the data,
and scholarship really close to the data,

98.11.text:
using large national data sets and understand
there's...it's at least part of the picture

102.97.text:
that's worth focusing on, the role of fathers
and the importance of family structure.

107.42.text:
Christina: And I think a lot of people are just not aware
that both liberal and conservative scholars

112.23.text:
are converging on this consensus that a culture
of fatherless is dysfunctional, whereas any

119.59.text:
child can come from a broken home and make
admirable adjustments. But to have millions

126.22.text:
of children coming from such homes, we're
normalizing it. We haven't taken the time

130.94.text:
to look at the consequences. You have and
your colleagues have. What sort of things

137.38.text:
are you finding; for example, the relationship
between poverty and fatherlessness? Brad:

142.89.text:
We know that families that are headed by married
parents are less likely to be poor than families

147.13.text:
headed by single mothers. Single moms are
five times more likely if they're heading

150.80.text:
up a family to be poor compared to married
parents. So that's one example of the way

155.21.text:
in which family structure is related to another
key outcome that all of us are concerned about,

160.25.text:
whether we're on the left or the right, that
is poverty and families, poverty among kids.

165.47.text:
So, we also have been talking a lot of late
about income inequality, and the data suggests

170.46.text:
there that about a third of the increase in
income inequality for families between the

174.28.text:
'70s and the 1990s was related to the retreat
from marriage. The fact that if your working

179.53.text:
class and poor families have a father in the
picture, a married father in the picture who

185.49.text:
would otherwise would've been contributing
economically to those families. So that's increasing

190.05.text:
the economic divide between college-educated
families who tend to be much more stable,

194.49.text:
more married, and working class and poor families,
who tend to be more likely today to be headed

199.47.text:
by a single parent, usually a single mother.
Christina: But what do you say to critics

202.79.text:
who say, "But, well, it's not that if they
get married then everything will be rosy.

210.52.text:
They can't get married because they are poor,
it's poverty. It's absence of jobs that's

216.16.text:
creating the social havoc, and it doesn't
allow them to get married," and that you're

221.72.text:
not looking at the root causes. What do you
say to that? Brad: Well, it's really the case

225.19.text:
that poverty is an issue, that issues related
to men's involvement in labor force, these

230.80.text:
are all major issues that help to explain
why it is that working class and poor Americans

235.36.text:
are today less likely to get married, but
that's not the whole story. And if we looked

240.21.text:
at this historically, for instance, at the
1930s, the height of The Great... Christina:

245.17.text:
Depression. Brad: ...Depression, there was
no dramatic increase in family instability,

249.03.text:
no dramatic increase in single parenthood,
no dramatic increase in divorce. So, part

253.69.text:
of what's happening right now is that the
changes in our culture are interacting with

259.02.text:
changes in the economy in ways that make working
class and poor relationships more fragile

265.12.text:
and less likely to either end in marriage
or to go the distance. So, class matters in

272.13.text:
all this, but also I think we have to acknowledge
ways in which culture matters and changes

277.22.text:
in the culture matter. Christina: Yeah, I
know our colleague, Charles Murray in his

281.54.text:
book Coming Apart, he mentioned how you go
back to the '40s or '50s and you look the

287.61.text:
wealthy, middle class, and poor, and of course,
the wealthy had better things and had lived

293.17.text:
at a much higher level of prosperity obviously.
But in many other ways, there weren't exact

303.71.text:
same levels of marriage but very close and
family stability, and also connection to community.

312.87.text:
And it appears that when you're married and
stay with your family, there's more likelihood

317.84.text:
to be involved in schools, and clubs, in social
organizations. Charles mentions that today,

327.65.text:
a lot of people say, "Oh, well, it's not Ozzie
and Harriet anymore." Well, it appears that

332.58.text:
is for the cognitive elite, for the upper
middle class. They do look rather like the

338.04.text:
1950s and their kids are benefitting from
it. And then you look at people that are lower

343.78.text:
middle class, poor, and there's not only the
poverty but also the social havoc, and kids

349.85.text:
not having the benefit of two parents, and
you're seeing this. Brad: Right. Yeah, and

355.13.text:
there's this growing class divide in American
family life and the irony is that well-educated

359.42.text:
Americans, who often are more progressive
in theory on family issues are, when it comes

363.55.text:
to their own marriages and the way that they
interact with their kids, quite conventional

370.55.text:
in a kind of neotraditional sense. Christina:
They don't preach what they practice, as Charles

374.68.text:
said. Brad: Exactly. So, there is this walking
right, talking left dynamic in play for some

381.55.text:
elites that is noteworthy. But the deeper
point here is that college-educated Americans

387.12.text:
have figured out important ways how to navigate
this new world when it comes to their own

394.52.text:
families. And they also benefit of course
from better incomes and more stable incomes.

398.78.text:
And so they're doing pretty well. And we've
actually seen divorce rates come down in college-educated

403.94.text:
precincts since 1980s. The example that I
give is Newt Gingrich versus Barack Obama.

409.03.text:
It's not a political point. It's a generational
point. I can't really imagine someone in Obama's

414.63.text:
position having the kind of marital history
that Newt Gingrich does. And so the point

418.48.text:
simply is that I think for many elites, their
orientation towards marriage and family life

424.11.text:
shifted in the late '80s and '90s and 2000s.
And so they have figured out that marriage

431.49.text:
matters for them and for their kids and they're
acting accordingly. Now the challenge, of

434.60.text:
course, facing us as a country is can we extend
that wisdom and those insights to the broader

440.58.text:
country and help rebuild working class and
poor marriages today as well? Christina: Well,

447.11.text:
tell me about the impact of fathers on kids,
and it's different for boys and girls. It's

456.39.text:
fashionable in some circle to say, "Well,
fathers or mothers, they're interchangeable."

460.25.text:
But common sense and maybe the entire anthropological
record suggests that the roles are different.

470.07.text:
Just to give a mandate example, I've seen
kids playing in the park, a child's on a climbing

474.10.text:
structure and the mother will say, "Be careful,
Timmy." And the dad will say, "Can you get

479.38.text:
to the top?" Just that sort of thing. I think
most people just see kids benefitting from

485.44.text:
both. And if you have only one parent, the
other is not there, but typically it's the father

492.08.text:
What do we know about the effects
on girls and young women? Brad: Well, it's

499.81.text:
interesting. When it comes to thinking about
the impact of dads on their daughters, what

503.72.text:
we see basically is that daughters are more
likely to flourish educationally and even

510.63.text:
later on in life professionally when they've
had an involved dad who's engaged with them

515.57.text:
in their lives. And so there's a way in which
both fatherhood and marriage done right, of

521.88.text:
course, are really, today, I think, acting
in service of the cause of women's progress.

528.94.text:
So my research, for instance, shows that young
women who have come from an intact family

533.09.text:
are more likely to be flourishing in their
late 20s compared to young women who haven't

537.94.text:
had that in their background. So again, there's
a way in which today girls benefit from having

543.35.text:
an active father in their life. Christina:
And this is across class lines? Brad: Across

546.47.text:
class lines. We also see too when it comes
to teen pregnancy that women who have a father

551.82.text:
present are much less likely to become pregnant
as teenagers and women who have a close emotional

557.35.text:
relationship with their dad are much less
likely to become pregnant as teenagers. So

560.95.text:
having both a father present in your life
and having an engaged and affectionate dad

565.54.text:
in your life is a real resource for our girls
here in the U.S. Christina: And I remember,

571.49.text:
and I've tried to debate this sometimes with
gender scholars and they never say much about

577.62.text:
it, but isn't it protective for children but
particularly girls with the father, the biological

585.95.text:
father in the home. The likelihood of violence
or sexual predation, it increases exponentially

595.07.text:
when the dad's gone and you have a mother's
live-in boyfriend. You've talked about that.

599.74.text:
Brad: Yeah, so the U.S. Department of Health
and Human Services publishes a report on a

604.05.text:
fairly regular basis on child abuse and child
neglect. It may have a figure that maps out

610.27.text:
or charts out the relationship between family
structure and child abuse, so the physical

615.84.text:
abuse of kids, the sexual abuse of kids, and
the emotional abuse of children. And I think

620.62.text:
they actually come out in boys and girls in
this particular figure, and there's a very

624.05.text:
strong association between family structure
and kids' safety on these three outcomes.

629.83.text:
And so kids who are being raised in an intact
biological married family have much lower

634.61.text:
rates of abuse than kids in other arrangements,
and the most risky place in America is where

640.14.text:
you have a biological parent and an unrelated
adult. They don't specify how that's arranged

644.55.text:
but that's typically the mom and an unrelated
male boyfriend, that's a much riskier place

649.08.text:
for our kids. They're about nine times more
likely to be physically, sexually, or emotionally

653.00.text:
abused in those relationships with family
contexts than kids who are being raised in

659.23.text:
intact married families. So that's just one
indication of the way in which, in this case,

663.59.text:
both girls and boys are safer from the scourge
of child abuse when they're being raised by

670.23.text:
their own married parents. Christina: And
I read in various reports and they wrote about

676.04.text:
this in the Oregon's Boys, the latest edition,
that boys from broken homes, especially poor

683.27.text:
boys, that this family instability has more
adverse effect on boys than girls. The daughters

689.87.text:
are, for whatever reason, appear to be doing
better educationally and vocationally. Brad:

695.32.text:
Yeah, no, it's interesting, it's ironic that
you had a colleague at Stanford who was an

699.84.text:
economist who was concerned about this point
about fathers because there's more evidence

703.42.text:
coming actually from economics specifically
that is suggestive here. Raj Chetty at Stanford,

710.47.text:
Marianne Bertrand at Chicago, especially David
Autor at MIT, they're doing work that suggest

717.23.text:
that poor boys in particular are being hit
hard by this retreat from marriage, that they

722.71.text:
are the ones who are most likely to be suspended
from school, for instance. And what's fascinating

727.15.text:
about David Autor's work is he's been doing
a research with colleagues in Florida and

732.21.text:
what they're finding is that generally speaking,
boys are more likely to be suspended than

736.42.text:
girls in school, but the gap between boys
and girls is much smaller for kids from more

742.29.text:
affluent families and much bigger for kids
from poor families. And a substantial part

747.26.text:
of that story is the kids from poor families
are more likely to have a single mother at

750.37.text:
the head of that household. And so, it's...
Christina: I read...yeah. Brad: So basically

754.26.text:
not having the father in the household is
one reason why poor boys, it looks like based

758.91.text:
upon Autor's work, are more likely to be suspended
from school. Christina: You've written about

764.11.text:
what fathers do for boys even in terms of
teaching them how to roughhouse and how to

772.58.text:
control their... Brad: Their bodies, yeah.
Christina: Tell us a little bit about that.

775.96.text:
Brad: So it's fascinating. When you think
about a dad roughhousing with his kids on

781.38.text:
Thursday night, maybe exasperating the mom.
She's like, "I'm trying to get kids to bed

786.32.text:
and here is my husband on the floor wrestling
with them," or on Saturday morning wrestling

792.21.text:
with his toddlers. And you might think, what's
the big deal? But what's interesting about

797.56.text:
this, is that work by Ross Parke, who is a
psychologist at University of California,

803.00.text:
indicates that this kind of rough-and-tumble
play on the part of fathers helps kids develop

812.66.text:
and that kids, both boys and girls, are more
likely to be doing well socially, popular

817.51.text:
in their classes if they have lots of rough-and-tumble
play with their father. And so I think the

822.96.text:
story here is that having that experience
with your dad basically teaches kids, to some

829.31.text:
extent, how to control their emotions and
their bodies and then they take that knowledge

833.99.text:
and they bring it with them into the classroom
or onto the soccer field or the football field

838.69.text:
or to the playground. Christina: And how to
be rambunctious and playful without being

843.63.text:
violent. Brad: Yeah, without being out of
control. Christina: That you can...without

844.94.text:
losing control. Brad: So if the kid is biting
or kicking his father in that, he soon learns

849.31.text:
that's not appropriate and that's not acceptable.
And so, they're taking some life lessons from

856.48.text:
the family room floor to their classroom,
and the playground, and the soccer field.

860.98.text:
Christina: So the girl, she'll have a mother
who's...so many single mothers are heroic

868.27.text:
and they're working so hard and the kids love
them and respect them, but the daughter also

873.28.text:
emulates her. And the son is less likely to
emulate a mother but more likely to for a

878.99.text:
male role model. And if the father is not
there, it'll be, well, we hope there's a surrogate,

884.63.text:
but if not, it would be friends, I guess,
or peers. Brad: Right, and so one of the things

890.22.text:
that David Autor is hypothesizing in his work,
again, showing that poor boys are being hit

894.66.text:
particularly hard by fatherlessness in their
communities. Autor at MIT, again, is thinking

902.00.text:
that what may be happening here is that poor
boys are often in a situation where they don't

906.03.text:
have regular access to in their own home to
a father who is going to work every day and

916.09.text:
who is involved as a husband and a father
in the home. And so that may affect how they

922.87.text:
approach school, how they approach work down
the road, and how they approach relationships

928.23.text:
as well. So again, not having that father
might be particularly salient for boys for

934.28.text:
the reasons that Autor has suggested in his
reports called Wayward Sons. It was well worth

939.13.text:
putting up on the Internet. Christina: Yes,
I was very impressed by that and did mention

943.90.text:
it in some of my research. I can imagine someone
saying, "Well, the kind of fathers who remain

952.76.text:
married and stay in the home, they're more
stable individuals," but you've actually shown,

959.50.text:
and others, that marriage and staying with
your kids, it changes the man. How does that

968.43.text:
work? Brad: So what you've been finding in
the research is that men are transformed by

977.96.text:
marriage and by married fatherhood, so men
who get married and stay married and have

983.32.text:
kids in marriage tend to work longer hours.
They tend to work more strategically. They're

987.72.text:
less likely to be fired, for instance, even
controlling for a range of background characteristics,

992.51.text:
and they make more money. Christina: They
also live longer and they're healthier. Brad:

995.13.text:
That's also true as well. Christina: Because
their wives make them go to the doctor, otherwise

997.58.text:
they won't. Brad: And also less likely to
be riding a motorcycle without a helmet and

1000.32.text:
less likely to be going to bars on Saturday
night, all that kind of stuff. So when men...

1003.20.text:
Christina: And more likely to be a little
nagged, but it's worth the health. Brad: Yes,

1006.77.text:
right. It's worth the long-term...yes, there's
a long-term benefit. So yeah, marriage has

1011.73.text:
a big impact on men's lives. And work done
by Harvard sociologists, for instance, suggests

1020.62.text:
that this marriage premium is highest among
men who are married in intact families with

1028.23.text:
their kids in the household. So having that
motivation to provide for your kids is a big

1033.15.text:
factor for many men. Christina: Yeah, so all
of these things, we look at the benefits for

1039.89.text:
women and, well, did we talk about that? Brad:
Well, it's an important, I think, point to

1044.49.text:
hit on actually because there was a time in
recent history when women were getting married

1052.06.text:
and they would pay a marriage penalty for
marriage. What's fascinating is that today,

1057.86.text:
it's a new world. And so, what we're seeing
from a new study at Columbia University, for

1062.16.text:
instance, is that we do...women still have
a motherhood penalty. Women are more likely

1067.06.text:
to withdraw to some extent from the labor
force when they have children. But what's

1070.35.text:
fascinating is that today married moms have
a smaller penalty than unmarried moms do.

1076.55.text:
And I think the story there probably is that
the married moms have a partner who's helping

1081.05.text:
them navigate the challenges of juggling work
and family, and maybe spelling them at certain

1087.37.text:
times, taking the kids at a certain times.
And having that husband in the picture makes

1092.30.text:
it easier for them to remain in the labor
force. So, the classic concern that marriage

1100.22.text:
was a patriarchal institution that held women
back, I think, in some important respects

1104.33.text:
needs to be revised, maybe even dramatically
revised in 2016. Christina: So it's just another

1110.05.text:
advantage that most professional, highly educated
women have; and poorer women, that's just

1119.49.text:
something else that's undermining their ability?
Brad: Right, so the way in which marriages

1125.21.text:
now are much more common in some ways and
more stable and secure in upper middle class

1130.64.text:
homes only further advantages not just men
and kids in those communities but also women

1137.23.text:
it looks like today, on average. Of course,
we have to talk about the exceptions and we

1141.29.text:
all know there are exceptions to the kinds
of things I'm talking about today. It's also

1143.71.text:
important to acknowledge that many kids who
are raised by, say, a single mother turn out

1147.79.text:
just fine. In fact, most kids raised by single
moms turn out okay. I was raised by a single

1153.86.text:
mom. I think mom did a good job with me and
my sister. We've turned out fine but... Christina:

1156.78.text:
Oh, I read about you. You were a bit of a
hell-raiser. You threw your lunch pail across

1162.72.text:
the cafeteria. Brad: That's true. I had a
summer camp experience. It was a little bit...yeah.

1169.70.text:
Christina: That and other things because...
Brad: Yeah. But I got through that experience.

1175.46.text:
So yeah, I think that it's important to acknowledge
in all these debates and discussions that

1178.76.text:
there are plenty of kids flourishing in non-traditional
families. At the same time, though, as a sociologist,

1186.93.text:
I would say that kids are more likely to struggle.
We don't have the benefit of intact married

1192.96.text:
family. Christina: Well, I wanted to ask you
about that because in my family, not my immediate

1197.77.text:
family but extended family and probably everyone's,
there have been a lot of broken marriages

1202.19.text:
and kids raised in different situations. And
I look at some of these kids, who in my opinion,

1209.11.text:
turned out very well. I think what would've
happened if their parents stayed together

1212.77.text:
and I think they would've been different.
I can't say for sure that it would be so much

1221.40.text:
better. They had a hard time, some of them,
but it also made them survivors. You look

1230.39.text:
today at these helicopter parents in these
upper middle class homes and some of the kids

1236.12.text:
that I'm seeing in college, and then you meet
working-class kids who had a more difficult

1240.44.text:
time or even some of the kids in my family
who had to be...you just wonder if there are

1245.91.text:
some advantages, I don't want to say advantages
because you wouldn't want to put someone through

1250.11.text:
that. But on the other hand, a lot of those
kids do seem, I don't know, seem to be a little

1256.44.text:
more, yeah, I can't even say well-adapted,
but just ready to take on the world than these

1263.57.text:
hyperprotected kids. Brad: Yeah, I think being
raised by a single mother can, I think, in

1267.37.text:
some ways, for instance, that's my experience,
can give you certain experiences that are

1275.09.text:
challenging in ways that actually do prepare
you later in life for a tough scenario once

1282.20.text:
or another. But I think we have to acknowledge
that on average, again, the average story

1286.25.text:
here is more risk for kids raised apart from
the intact married families. Another important

1290.72.text:
point here... Christina: That's a good point.
It's a risk. It's not saying this will happen,

1294.69.text:
it just says maybe 25% of kids from broken
homes are going to run into serious problem.

1305.61.text:
The percentage is a lot lower. Brad: And different
kids experience family instability differently.

1310.07.text:
There's a fascinating new study from my mentor
at Princeton, Sara McLanahan, looking at genes

1314.53.text:
actually and father absence. And what she
is finding is it looks like some boys have

1320.00.text:
a genetic risk for acting in an antisocial
way, and it's those boys, not all boys, but

1327.66.text:
those boys who are more likely to be affected
on that outcome when their dad is absent from

1332.73.text:
the home. So again... Christina: But boys
with that gene and the father's in the home...

1336.97.text:
Brad: Yeah, but the complex of genes that
are related to this. Christina: They can't...it's

1339.72.text:
hard to... Brad: So there's a way in which
there may be an interaction between nature

1342.04.text:
and nurture here, so that some kids, again,
are being affected more by, in this case,

1347.72.text:
fatherlessness than other kids. And so other
kids are going to be pretty resilient in the
